territory.notes: In 1815, the colonies of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao were merged into a single colony, Curaçao and Dependencies. In 1828, seven Dutch colonies—Aruba, Bonaire, Curaçao, Saba, Sint Eustatius, Sint Maarten, and Suriname—were combined into a single colony, Dutch West Indies, governed out of Paramaribo, Suriname. In 1845, the Dutch West Indies was divided into two separate colonies, Suriname and Curaçao and Dependencies; the latter included Aruba, Bonaire, Curaçao, Saba, Sint Eustatius, and Sint Maarten. In 1948, the colony’s name was changed to the Netherlands Antilles.
